title: 114_hr3869
content: The Act titled "State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015" focuses on coordinating cybersecurity efforts between state and local governments with the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection focusing on State and Local Coordination on Cybersecurity. This amendment aims to assist State and local governments in identifying information system vulnerabilities and security protections in line with cybersecurity risks. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include provisions for cybersecurity protections for information collected or maintained by State or local governments, as well as information systems used by agencies or contractors on behalf of State or local governments. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include cybersecurity provisions for State and local governments, providing tools and resources through a web portal and coordinating efforts with government officials. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include cybersecurity provisions for State and local governments, providing tools, products, resources, policies, guidelines, and procedures related to information security. This includes offering operational and technical cybersecurity training to government analysts and operators, as well as privacy and civil rights coordination with department officers. The Department's Liberties Officer provides cybersecurity training and technical assistance to State and local governments for implementing information security tools and resources. This includes deploying technology to diagnose and mitigate cyber threats without reimbursement. The Department's Liberties Officer provides cybersecurity training and technical assistance to State and local governments for implementing information security tools and resources, including compiling and analyzing data on State and local information security, and developing policies for coordinating vulnerability disclosures. The Department's Liberties Officer provides cybersecurity training and technical assistance to State and local governments for implementing information security tools and resources, including coordinating vulnerability disclosures and ensuring compliance with national and international standards in the information technology industry. The Department's cybersecurity training includes privacy and civil liberties training that aligns with Fair Information Practice Principles and limits the use and disclosure of cybersecurity-related information. The curr_chunk discusses the disclosure of cybersecurity information related to specific individuals that is not necessary for cybersecurity purposes, with a focus on minimizing impact on privacy and civil liberties, and ensuring data integrity through the removal of obsolete or erroneous personal information. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need to safeguard cyber threat indicators and defensive measures, including proprietary or business-sensitive information, to prevent unauthorized access or acquisition. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center of the Department of Homeland Security must provide information to congressional committees on cybersecurity activities within 2 years of the Act's enactment, ensuring constitutional, legal, and privacy protections are upheld. The Senate Governmental Affairs committee will assess the effectiveness of cybersecurity activities under the Homeland Security Act of 2002, specifically focusing on State and local information security. Feedback from State and local governments will be incorporated into the assessment. The House of Representatives passed the information required under this subsection on December 10, 2015. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
